Issues.Title: False Props Shorthand (false-assertion operator)
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Currently, you can set a `true` value on a prop by simply using the prop's name (i.e. `<input readonly...>`), but there is no equivalence for setting `false` values (i.e. `<input :readonly="false">`).

In most cases (like above), `false` is already the default value, but there are still many instances where a prop's default is `true` and must be overridden. The API is cumbersome in those instances.

### What does the proposed API look like?
I'm proposing a simple, in-template, "false-assertion" shorthand that could significantly improve the Vue developer experience. The "false-assertion" operator would explicitly set props to `false`.

### Current API
```<input :readonly="false"/>```

### Proposed API
```<input !readonly/>```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "False Props Shorthand (false-assertion operator)" (#11562)

Issues.Title: Upgrade to the latest version (serialize-javascript)
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://www.npmjs.com/package/serialize-javascript](https://www.npmjs.com/package/serialize-javascript)







### Steps to reproduce
serialize-javascript is a package to serialize JavaScript to a superset of JSON that includes regular expressions and functions. Affected versions of this package are vulnerable to Arbitrary Code Injection. An object like {"foo": /1"/, "bar": "a\"@__R-<UID>-0__@"} would be serialized as {"foo": /1"/, "bar": "a\/1"/}, meaning an attacker could escape out of bar if they controlled both foo and bar and were able to guess the value of <UID>. UID is generated once on startup, is chosen using Math.random() and has a keyspace of roughly 4 billion, so within the realm of an online attack. eval('('  serialize({"foo": /1"   console.log(1)/i, "bar": '"@__R-<UID>-0__@'})   ')');

### What is expected?
Upgrade to the latest version

### What is actually happening?
serialize-javascript is a package to serialize JavaScript to a superset of JSON that includes regular expressions and functions. Affected versions of this package are vulnerable to Arbitrary Code Injection. An object like {"foo": /1"/, "bar": "a\"@__R-<UID>-0__@"} would be serialized as {"foo": /1"/, "bar": "a\/1"/}, meaning an attacker could escape out of bar if they controlled both foo and bar and were able to guess the value of <UID>. UID is generated once on startup, is chosen using Math.random() and has a keyspace of roughly 4 billion, so within the realm of an online attack. eval('('  serialize({"foo": /1"   console.log(1)/i, "bar": '"@__R-<UID>-0__@'})   ')');

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Upgrade to the latest version (serialize-javascript)" (#11561)

Issues.Title: client-plugin generates a wrong client.manifest.json
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/maunier/test-vue-ssr.git](https://github.com/maunier/test-vue-ssr.git)







### Steps to reproduce
```
npm i
npm run build
npm run start
visit: http://127.0.0.1:3000/c2
```

### What is expected?
1. I expect  'pages/c2.xxx.js' is loaded by html, but it is loaded by runtime

2. I expect that ,   in .nuxt/dist/server/client.manifest.json , pages/c2.xx.js will be included by any module, but it's not

for example, I expect:
```
"all" [
  "0.xxx.js",
  "1.xxx.js",
  "pages/c2.xxx.js"
],
"modules": {
  "module1": [0], // 0.xxx.js
  "module2": [1], // 1.xxx.js
  "module3": [2] // "pages/c2.xxx.js"
}
```
I expect there should be one module(module3) that contains the 'pages/c2.xxx.js', so that when I visit /c2, pages.c2.xxx.js can be  loaded by html other than the runtime.js

### What is actually happening?
actually the json is like this:
```
"all" [
  "0.xxx.js",
  "1.xxx.js",
  "pages/c2.xxx.js"
],
"modules": {
  "module1": [0], // 0.xxx.js
  "module2": [1], // 1.xxx.js
}
```

there is no module that contains 'pages/c2.xxx.js'. 

---
when I remove 'import { fn } from '@@/utils/fn''  in src/pages/c2.vue, everything is ok, but I don't know why

Issues.Title: Support provide/inject on functional components that are the immediate descendant of the provider
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
[This comment](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/5194#issuecomment-465964034) from #5194 covers the use case quite well. In short, there is no way to do the following:

```html
<SomeProvider foo="bar">
    <FunctionalFoo/>
</SomeProvider>
```

The inner functional component cannot access any injected properties.

This occurs because the FC is rendered in the nearest vue context, which happens to be the provider in this case, and it's not possible to inject and provide within the same component.

### What does the proposed API look like?
The same as now, but supporting injections in functional components that are the immediate children of a provider.

This could either be achieved by supporting injections inside the same component as the provider, or passing the injections down similar to how we pass props down.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support provide/inject on functional components that are the immediate descendant of the provider" (#11559)

Issues.Title: Toggling binded class causes classes that were added on a custom directive to get removed
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/hafez/nobjg618/](https://jsfiddle.net/hafez/nobjg618/)

### Steps to reproduce
1. define a custom directive that adds a class to element's class list.
2. use this defined directive on an element and toggle a random class via `v-bind:class`

### What is expected?
Static classes of the element and classes that are added on directive should stay untouched.

### What is actually happening?
When toggling a dynamic class, all classes added on directive get removed.

Issues.Title: v-else preventing update of variables in nested slots
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/n8bkg4pw/](https://jsfiddle.net/n8bkg4pw/)







### Steps to reproduce
When clicking on the `inc` button, the displays of `nb_foo.value` will change of value but one out of the three won't change of value because of the bug.

### What is expected?
All of the display of `nb_foo.value` to change of value

### What is actually happening?
One out of the three display of `nb_foo.value` won't change of value because of the bug.

---
It's only happening when in a `v-else` itself in the slot of the `fake` component. When inverting the condition (putting the second `fake` in a `v-if` instead of a `v-else`) it's properly working.

I encountered this error with a much more complex example with two components nested in a similar way.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "v-else preventing update of variables in nested slots" (#11553)

Issues.Title: Update object value in a loop getting the same value on all items using Vue
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63168829/update-object-value-in-a-loop-getting-the-same-value-on-all-items-using-vue](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63168829/update-object-value-in-a-loop-getting-the-same-value-on-all-items-using-vue)







### Steps to reproduce
Run in a loop which should update some values inside an object.
I tried map, foreach & for loops but the specific property (e.g Id, or show) getting always the same values.
I took the same logic to jsfiddle and it's worked there.

For instance, 
button.id getting always the same id for all the buttons. button.show can be true or false but always the same at all buttons no matter what loop i'm using, the console show the expected value, then after the loop, it is strange, the property is added but with the same values all over.





### What is expected?
Object array values should update by its new value

### What is actually happening?
Object array values updated the same as the first value initialed
for all other arrays.

---
You can see how it works in jsfiddle - https://jsfiddle.net/4scx6L2t/1/
I Asked and added my logic in Stack Overflow - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63168829/update-object-value-in-a-loop-getting-the-same-value-on-all-items-using-vue

Issues.Title: Building a vue library is including the @vue/cli-service build command in the output bundle
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/Robin-Hoodie/vue-test-project](https://github.com/Robin-Hoodie/vue-test-project)


### Steps to reproduce
- `vue create test-project` (choose default preset with babel/eslint)
- Add `src/index.js` file which exports generated HelloWorld component `export * from ./components/HelloWorld.vue`
- Create `vue.config.js` file and add `webpack-bundle-analyzer` plugin to webpack config (this is just to inspect the bundle size)
- Change `build` command to `vue-cli-service build --target lib --name test-project src/index.js`
- Run `yarn build`
- Inspect generated `dist/report.html` file
- Notice `@vue/cli-service/lib/commands/build` is included in bundle

### What is expected?
Since `@vue/cli-service` is a `devDependency` I do not expect anything of this dependency to be included in the output bundle

### What is actually happening?
`@vue/cli-service/lib/commands/build` is included in the output bundle

---
I am developing a component library for internal use. I noticed the bundle was quite big and upon inspecting the output I noticed the `@vue/cli-service/lib/commands/build` was being included. 

I had already added quite a lot of components, which may be the cause for that dependency taking in a lot more space than in the test project I created (34.63 KB gzipped vs 1.25 KB gzipped)

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Building a vue library is including the @vue/cli-service build command in the output bundle" (#11545)

Issues.Title: Element client dimensions reported wrongly.
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link

My code is too complicated to break down into a simple fiddle. I am really not experienced enough to create one. I am happy to work with you to debug the issue. If you ignore all issues from people who struggle with creating minimal reproduction examples in an environment they are unfamiliar with you will end up with lots of bugs. I have spent a lot of time to make this bug report as thorough as possible to compensate for the lack of a fiddle.

I even tried to create a fiddle, but could not figure out what to click to generate a link to paste here. Yes, I am a fiddle noob! I am sure it is one of those things that is REALLY obvious once you know how, but I was expecting to see a big button with "GENERATE LINK" in large letters. There isn't one.

### Steps to reproduce

I am creating a web app as a single non-scrollable page and am finding myself needing to exercise a lot of control on element sizes. There are tables within tables and some cells are explicitly pixel sized and some are percentage sized.

I am using Firefox.

One of these tables within a table (within a table) contains 6 identical Vue components (with different IDs so that they get fed with different data)  based on a canvas. The Firefox element inspector reports all the elements as having the same height as each other (as they are all in cells in the same row this is expected) and as the cells that contain them.

In the mounted() function of the component I do this:

        var el = this.$el;
        this.context = el.getContext("2d");
        this.context.canvas.width = el.clientWidth;
        this.context.canvas.height = el.clientHeight;

I have also tried putting the above code in a Resize() function and doing the following in mounted():

        setTimeout(this.Resize.bind(this), 1000);

I have also tried using $nextTick().

### What is expected?
The canvas is resized to the element size. Drawing, which is based on the size of the canvas is correct. The drawn content displays crisply and perfectly.

### What is actually happening?
el.clientHeight is being reported incorrectly and the canvas is being stretched to fit the element's real size. The display is fuzzy and poor.

Adding debug as follows:

        console.log("ID="   el.id   ", w="   el.clientWidth   ", h="   el.clientHeight   ", pw="   el.parentElement.clientWidth   ", ph="   el.parentElement.clientHeight);

outputs the following:

    ID=port_swivel, w=74, h=291, pw=82, ph=291
    ID=port_thrust, w=74, h=293, pw=82, ph=293
    ID=ballast, w=74, h=295, pw=82, ph=295
    ID=stbd_thrust, w=74, h=297, pw=82, ph=297
    ID=stbd_swivel, w=74, h=299, pw=82, ph=299
    ID=light_power, w=66, h=301, pw=74, ph=301

Firefox reports the real element size as 300.55.

---
I found this article which is where I got the idea of using a timeout - as reported it didn't help.

https://github.com/vuejs/Discussion/issues/394

If I add similar debug to my Redraw() function, I can see that:

1) The Redraw() is somehow being called before mounted(), and the element's width and height are correctly reported.

2) When Redraw( is called by Resize() (when called directly by mounted()) the height is reported as being 2 pixels bigger in Redraw(0 than in Resize().

 3) All subsequent calls to Redraw() get the height correct.

So whenever the execution path is NOT through mounted() the height is correct, but when the execution path is through mounted(), even when using setTimeout() or $nextTick(), the height is incorrect.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Element client dimensions reported wrongly." (#11539)

Issues.Title: DOM element attribute being set empty after component root object update
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/uxz2dnqv/](https://jsfiddle.net/uxz2dnqv/)







### Steps to reproduce
Using minimal reproduction: in the top select, change from 0 to 1. Then, inspect bottom select: the "Input 0" option should have the static attribute value="s0" as defined in the Vue.js template, but instead has value="".

`<option v-if="!specSet['s0']" value="s0">Input 0</option>`

### What is expected?
I thought Vue.js should refresh the UI after changing top select from 0 to 1 so that the Input 0 option appears, with value="s0".

`<option value="s0">Input 0</option>`

### What is actually happening?
Vue.js refreshes the UI and adds the Input 0 option, but its value attribute is set to empty string.

`<option value="">Input 0</option>`

---
It may be related to #11398

I have a parent component X with nested attribute X.Y.Z, and a child component that is given property referencing X.Y.Z.

The child component has a select input with options that appear depending on X.Y.Z.

When X.Y is updated (after changing the top select in the minimal reproduction), the options in the select input are updated but their attributes are not updated correctly.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "DOM element attribute being set empty after component root object update" (#11538)

Issues.Title: SSR rendered component has no attributed updated but does have content updated
Issues.Body: ### Version 2.6.11 ### Reproduction link [https://jsfiddle.net/hvqctx21/](https://jsfiddle.net/hvqctx21/) ### Steps to reproduce Run the fiddle. It emulates a case when the server side rendered component doesn't match the browser render result. ### What is expected? The "I'm red" text should be red indeed. Also it's wrapper should have the 'some-attr' attribute. ### What is actually happening? The "I'm red" text has the server side rendered class 'blue'. Also the 'some-attr' is absent. --- Any update action turn the things right. E.g. if you click the "I'm red" text the adjacent 'span' is updated but the whole component wrapper also gets the correct attributes. Also (and this is a workaround) it works fine if the SSR provides any other block type. E.g. ``` ``` In this case the 'span' is properly replaced by the 'div' with suitable attributes. Sorry for possible duplicate: tried to search the same case but no result. We use Vue 2.6.6 on our production but the behavior is the same for 2.6.11 in the Jsfiddle. For some reason if I use the Jsfiddle Vue boilerplate template it works as expected. Unfortunately we can't provide the matching content form SSR: it's created by a 3rd-party library which doesn't support SSR yet.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "SSR rendered component has no attributed updated but does have content updated" (#11536)

I don't know if this is the proper way to fix this issue, but I will give some examples below that worked for me:

PS*: Check the `foo` param

![WORK-route-matching_params_%252520-working_bar](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20761700/88710389-f933c400-d0ec-11ea-8eaa-4c136c28a4ba.png)


This example was also broking:

Strange thing is, when I click the Back button in my browser (Chrome), it takes my Vue app in iframe one page back instead of doing that with parent page (mail.google.com).
How can I make it that clicking browserâs back button affect only parent page (mail.google.com) and not my Vue app in appended iframe?

Clicking on Chrome's  Back button should navigate parent webpage one step backwards.

### What is actually happening?
Clicking on Chrome's  Back button navigates my iframe with vue-router app instead.

Issues.Title: Named and dynamic routes
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
This allows for a named route to take priority over a dynamic route. Useful in getting some otherwise rather messy logic out of the templates.
i.e. a blog route with an archive page

The end user experience is likely to be better as developers will have more time to work on other things and not coming up with hacky ways to parse a param. 


### What does the proposed API look like?
{path: '/blog/archive/:date(.*)', component: blogArchivePage},
{path: '/blog/category/:categoryName', component: blogCategoryPage},
{path: '/blog/:postName', component: blogPost},
{path: '/products/ourAmazingFlagshipProduct', component: amazingProduct},
{path: '/products/:theRestLessExcitingProducts', component: lessAmazingProducts}

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Named and dynamic routes" (#3264)

Issues.Title: Select Close to throw a redirect error
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?

when router has redirect I got this error: `Redirected when going from "/a" to "/b" via a navigation guard.`

I found this line of code(**199-200**):

[https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/b0ef4974aa4a8a6a4865717f1fad50954379800a/src/history/base.js#L194-L209](https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/b0ef4974aa4a8a6a4865717f1fad50954379800a/src/history/base.js#L194-L209)

Redirection is a commonly used function, I think that this error should not be thrown frequently or provide a function to choose whether to throw an error.


By the way, why should this exception be thrown, and what is its purpose?

> I use Google Translate, which may cause difficulty in understanding...




### What does the proposed API look like?
```
// like this
interface NavigationGuardOptions {
  throwError: boolean
}
export type NavigationGuardNext<V extends Vue = Vue> = (
  to?: RawLocation | false | ((vm: V) => any) | void,
  options: NavigationGuardOptions
) => void
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: ChunkLoadError: Loading chunk chunk-x failed.
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.3.2

I'm using the latest Vue versions with Vue Router, and Vue Composition API.
Since I deployed my project, I catch every few days (I guess, every deployment), a `ChunkLoadError` exception in Sentry.

I'm not sure why it happens, I don't have any custom Webpack configurations.

This is the exception:
```
ChunkLoadError: Loading chunk chunk-626fe0ff failed.
(timeout: https://example.com/js/chunk-626fe0ff.248f3eae.js)
  at (timeout: (/js/chunk-626fe0ff.248f3eae.js))
  at Function.s.e(webpack/bootstrap:126:18)
  at cb(src/pages/Inquiry.vue:67:1)
  at apply(./node_modules/@vue/composition-api/dist/vue-composition-api.module.js:932:9)
  at index(./node_modules/@vue/composition-api/dist/vue-composition-api.module.js:891:20)
  at flushQueue(./node_modules/@vue/composition-api/dist/vue-composition-api.module.js:818:15)
  at call(./node_modules/@vue/composition-api/dist/vue-composition-api.module.js:830:17)
  at i(./node_modules/vue/dist/vue.runtime.esm.js:1980:12)
  at flushCallbacks(./node_modules/vue/dist/vue.runtime.esm.js:1906:12)
```

The weird part is that the chunk file still exists, so I'm not sure what this exception is about. Any guidance, what should I check? It happens in production only, not locally. I'm using Amazon Amplify to host the app.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Vue crashes when using history.state.key as the key of <Router-view> Wrapped in <Keep-alive>
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.3.4

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/soulsands/zhykod58/3](https://jsfiddle.net/soulsands/zhykod58/3)







### Steps to reproduce
click about

### What is expected?
show the about instance and the page stay normal 

### What is actually happening?
the about instance doesn't show  and the app crashes that  it  doesn't show page again no matter which router link you click. 

---
the reason is that router.replace use the same key while the keep-alive uses the key of  a vnode to track the caches. 
when I click the About link, the key of About Vnode is the same as Home's. so the keep-alive use the cache of home to render the About vnode.
```js
// keep-alive's render method
if (cache[key]) {
          vnode.componentInstance = cache[key].componentInstance;
          // make current key freshest
          remove(keys, key);
          keys.push(key);
        } 
```
I hijacked the go\back\replace methods of router setting a flag when I use those methods and manually set a new key to Router-view. 

this strategy is quite useful, at least for me. it's quite similar to browser's bfcache. Keep-alive only hits cache when user click back or forward button of browser and use a new page otherwise.

but I still think the key should be corresponding to the change of the routes. I think it represents the identifier of a URL or a page. when you replace a page with a new page, the key should be a new key too. 

and maybe router should use a new key too when using webpack hot reloads.

looks it's compatible if the replace methord use a new key since Router just use these keys to support the scroll-behavior feature, 

By the way, I found some inconsistent behavior about the key in history when loading a page.

say the app is running at  http://localhost:8080/

-  open a new tab and fill with  http://localhost:8080/ , the key is a number. reload the page then the key is the same number
-  open a new tab and fill with  http://localhost:8080/#/ , the key is null.  reload the page then the key is null.

all above are loading a page, but the keys are totally different. 

I think it's a good idea to provide a method to get the current key Router maintained  and it's also a good idea to provide a built-in mechanism to support bfcache in vue app





<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Vue crashes when using history.state.key as the key of <Router-view> Wrapped in <Keep-alive>" (#3254)

Issues.Title: Slow registerModule when the module has getters
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.5.1

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/qaL8f36y/](https://jsfiddle.net/qaL8f36y/)







### Steps to reproduce
0. Open the link
1. Specify any number > 0 for 'getters'
2. Click Generate Modules
3. Click Generate Modules

I was unable to generate more than about 3000 getters in total before the browser crashed.

Without the link, call Store.registerModule to register 1000s of modules with a single getter (or fewer modules with more getters) to see the browser run out of resources.

You can test out creating modules without getters and notice that the time taken is more-or-less constant (~45ms for me)

### What is expected?
Registering modules with getters should perform the same as modules without getters

### What is actually happening?
Performance of Store.registerModule when the module has getters is compounding, the more getters you have the slower it is to add more modules with getters.

---
I'm using dynamic modules as a pattern to handle 'collections of objects' in the store while avoiding needing to pass the index (or object key) around in getters, mutators, etc. Similar to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44345704/separating-vuex-stores-for-dynamically-created-components - I have hundreds of objects in the store that are treated this way.

I noticed an issue when using the dev tools as the dev tools would frequently crash, and sometimes the page would too. There were repeated warning in the console `[Violation] 'setTimeout' handler took 1552ms` where the time was increasing each time, which I took to mean something wasn't linear/constant time. I finally took the time to create a minimal reproduction but found the issue was present without Vue/Vuex devtools open, though the numbers needed to crash the browser were larger without devtools.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Typscript compile error - logger.d.ts missing in NPM package
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.5.0

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/chrisvfritz/50wL7mdz/](https://jsfiddle.net/chrisvfritz/50wL7mdz/)







### Steps to reproduce
Create default typescript project:

vue create test

? Please pick a preset: Manually select features
? Check the features needed for your project: Babel, TS, Router, Vuex, Linter
? Use class-style component syntax? No
? Use Babel alongside TypeScript (required for modern mode, auto-detected polyfills, transpiling JSX)? Yes
? Use history mode for router? (Requires proper server setup for index fallback in production) No
? Pick a linter / formatter config: Prettier
? Pick additional lint features: Lint on save
? Where do you prefer placing config for Babel, ESLint, etc.? In dedicated config files

cd test
npm run serve


### What is expected?
Expects to compile without errors.

### What is actually happening?

Issues.Title: feat: include logger plugin to the core export
Issues.Body:
This PR add `logger` plugin to the core export to be able to support ESM build for the `logger` plugin. Issue was mentioned at https://github.com/vitejs/vite/issues/334.

This is for Vuex 3, so I'm keeping the individual bundle as is to avoid braking change. For Vuex 4, I'm planning to remove the logger bundle entirely.

Planning to follow up the PR with documentation update as well for the next release.

Issues.Title: Vuex hasModule
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.4.0

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/hasmodule-inconsistent-with-string-x58fh?file=/src/App.vue](https://codesandbox.io/s/hasmodule-inconsistent-with-string-x58fh?file=/src/App.vue)







### Steps to reproduce
Check for the existence of a nested module with a string, vs an array path.

### What is expected?
I would expect checking with a string or an equivalent array to produce the same result.

### What is actually happening?
Checking `hasModule` with a string returns false, while checking it with an equivalent array returns true.

---
I suppose this could be intentional, but it seems like a bug.  If it's not intentional it seems like a simple fix:

Line 219 in `src/store.js ` currently is:

```if (typeof path === 'string') path = [path]```

It seems like simply changing that to the following will fix the problem:

```if (typeof path === 'string') path = path.split("/")```

Thoughts?

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
